content: The National Center for Sleep Disorders Research is established within the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. It will be headed by a Director appointed by the Institute's Director and will focus on research related to sleep disorders. The National Center for Sleep Disorders Research, established within the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, focuses on conducting and supporting biomedical research, disseminating health information, and conducting programs related to various sleep disorders and circadian rhythm research. The National Center for Sleep Disorders Research, established within the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, may award grants, conduct clinical trials, support research centers, collect epidemiology data, and conduct a National Education Campaign on sleep disorders. The National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, along with other Institutes, support ongoing research and grant activities. They coordinate with other federal agencies, public entities, and private entities. They can appoint peer review groups with approval from the Director of the National Institutes of Health. The National Institutes of Health, in consultation with advisory boards and committees, develop a comprehensive plan for sleep disorders research priorities and coordination. The plan is revised as needed. A coordinating committee is established for this purpose. The Director of the National Institutes of Health establishes the Sleep Disorders Coordinating Committee, composed of directors from various institutes and federal agencies, to make recommendations on sleep disorders research priorities. The Sleep Disorders Coordinating Committee makes recommendations to the Director of the National Institutes of Health and the Center regarding the content of the plan required in section 464Z, activities carried out in conjunction with other agencies of the National Institutes of Health, and activities with other agencies of the Federal Government. The Sleep Disorders Coordinating Committee advises the Director of the National Institutes of Health and the Center on the plan required in section 464Z, activities with other agencies of the National Institutes of Health, and activities with other agencies of the Federal Government. The Director of the National Institutes of Health will establish the Sleep Disorders Research Advisory Board to advise on scientific activities and policies of the Center. The Advisory Board will consist of 12 public representatives appointed by the Director, who are not federal government officers or employees. The Sleep Disorders Research Advisory Board consists of 12 public representatives appointed by the Director of the National Institutes of Health, with eight members from health and scientific disciplines related to sleep disorders and four representing individuals undergoing treatment for sleep disorders. Additionally, six officials serve as ex officio members of the Advisory Board. The Advisory Board includes key officials such as the Director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, the Director of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, the Assistant Secretary for Health, the Assistant Secretary of Defense (Health Affairs), and the Chief Medical Director of the Veterans' Administration. The members of the Advisory Board designate a chairperson from among themselves, and the provisions of section 406 apply to the advisory board in a similar manner as they do to any advisory council established under such section. The Secretary of Transportation, Defense, and Education are authorized to collect data, conduct studies, and disseminate public information on the impact of sleep disorders and deprivation on transportation safety, military readiness, and learning. They are also authorized to coordinate these activities with the Center. The Secretary of Labor and Commerce are authorized to collect data, conduct studies, and disseminate public information on the impact of sleep disorders and deprivation in the workplace, industry, and commerce. They are also authorized to coordinate these activities with the Center.
